summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York on July 24, 2020, commanding an unnamed recipient to appear before the grand jury on August 23, 2020, to testify and produce documents related to alleged violations of federal statutes including sex trafficking and conspiracy. The document includes a cover letter requesting confidentiality and an advice of rights notice.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Issued the grand jury subpoena as the Acting United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: The subpoena commands the recipient to appear before the grand jury at the United States Courthouse in Manhattan to testify and produce documents.

events.title: Subpoena Issued
events.description: The grand jury subpoena was issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office, initiating the formal command for testimony and document production.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
keyFacts: The subpoena is part of an official criminal investigation of a suspected felony being conducted by a federal grand jury in the Southern District of New York.

The investigation involves alleged violations of multiple federal statutes, including 18 U.S.C. §§ 1591 (sex trafficking), 2421-2423 (transportation for prostitution, coercion, and sexual activity with minors), 371 (conspiracy), and 1623 (false statements).
The U.S. Attorney's Office requested the recipient voluntarily refrain from disclosing the existence of the subpoena to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation.
The recipient is commanded to appear on August 23, 2020, at 10:00 a.m. and to produce items listed in an attached rider (not included in this text).
The document includes an 'Advice of Rights' notice informing the recipient of their right to refuse to answer incriminating questions and their right to counsel.
